general_usage.use_when: Apply when implementing this pattern in your domain context
general_usage.code_example:
# general_usage pattern for mcp-selection-guide
# Implement based on description: See detailed sections below...
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code
Start with minimal starter packs and add servers incrementally based on actual project needs rather than selecting everything upfront
Review authentication requirements for each server before selection - ensure you can obtain necessary API keys, tokens, or OAuth credentials
Consider server transport types (stdio vs SSE) - stdio servers run locally while SSE servers require network connectivity
Verify server compatibility with your operating system and runtime environment before adding to configuration
Group servers by category (core, code, data, cloud, collab, aiml) to understand dependencies and related functionality
Check server documentation and setup steps before configuration - some servers require additional setup beyond MCP config
Test server connectivity and authentication after configuration to ensure proper integration before production use
Monitor server resource usage and performance - some servers (like browser automation) can be resource-intensive

anti_patterns.name: Over-Selecting Servers
anti_patterns.problem: Adding too many MCP servers at once increases configuration complexity, authentication overhead, and resource usage. Many servers may go unused, wasting setup time and potential API costs.
anti_patterns.fix: Start with essential servers (filesystem, git, memory) and add additional servers incrementally as specific needs arise. Use starter packs as a baseline and customize based on actual requirements.

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Authentication Requirements
anti_patterns.problem: Selecting servers without checking authentication needs leads to configuration failures. OAuth servers require browser-based setup, API key servers need credentials, and some servers have no authentication.
anti_patterns.fix: Review authentication type for each server before selection. Prepare API keys, tokens, or OAuth credentials in advance. Use the authenticationSummary section to understand requirements.

anti_patterns.name: Mismatched Server Selection for Role
anti_patterns.problem: Selecting servers not aligned with your role (e.g., data science servers for frontend development) adds unnecessary complexity and unused capabilities, making configuration harder to maintain.
anti_patterns.fix: Use roleToServers mappings to guide selection. Start with essential servers for your role, then add recommended servers based on specific project needs. Review category descriptions to understand when each server is useful.

anti_patterns.name: Not Testing Server Configuration
anti_patterns.problem: Adding servers to configuration without testing leads to runtime failures, authentication errors, and wasted debugging time when agents try to use unavailable servers.
anti_patterns.fix: Test each server after configuration by verifying connectivity, authentication, and basic tool execution. Check server logs for errors and ensure environment variables are properly set.

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Transport Type Differences
anti_patterns.problem: Not understanding the difference between stdio (local) and SSE (remote) servers causes confusion when some servers work locally while others require network access. Remote servers may have latency and availability concerns.
anti_patterns.fix: Check the transport field for each server. Prefer stdio servers for local operations when possible. For SSE servers, ensure network connectivity and consider latency implications. Document which servers are remote.
